text: The most interesting (and physiologically well-supported) theory for sleep I’ve heard is that lying down and shutting down consciousness allows the brain hemolymph ducts to relax and thus to wash out metabolism waste products. The brain is so convoluted that fluid movement is too slow under normal use

Tangent, but this reminded me that there's a nature paper in 2015 that's basically just "hey, the brain has lymphatic vessels." Which, of course it does, but someone got a Nature paper from it :man-shrugging: <https://www.nature.com/articles/nature14432|https://www.nature.com/articles/nature14432>

That lymph appears to be different than the stuff the article <@U73KENNG4> linked refers to though.

attachments.title: Structural and functional features of central nervous system lymphatic vessels
attachments.text: The central nervous system undergoes constant immune surveillance, but the route that immune cells take to exit the brain has been unclear as it had been thought to lack a classical lymphatic drainage system; here functional lymphatic vessels able to carry both fluid and immune cells from the cerebrospinal fluid are shown to be located in the brain meninges.
